repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - National Program for Community
            Empowerment in Rural Areas Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the National Program for
            Community Empowerment in Rural Areas Project for Indonesia
            were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was moderate; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory; and borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes:
            adoption and funding by the government: a popular and robust
            series of Bank-led projects with demonstrated success in
            rural poverty reduction and improved governance, can lead to
            a massive national program led and largely funded by the
            Government. It can also mobilize significantly increased
            counterpart funding, at national and local levels, to
            achieve country-wide coverage. The use of a Multi donor
            Trust Fund improved implementation and successful
            experimentation: a successful series of projects, thoroughly
            evaluated, documented and publicized, can attract bilateral
            donors through linked trust funds and parallel financing
            operations. Rapid and large scaling up of a program's
            operation can exceed institutional capacity: in Program
            Nasional Pemberdayaan Masyarakat (PNPM)-rural first and
            second, the major expansion of the scope and scale of the
            project following its adoption as a national program, put
            severe stress on the institutional capacities at the
            national level, especially Directorate General of Village
            Community Empowerment (PMD) and for the National Management
            Consultant (NMC). Evaluation studies and use of their
            findings: well-conceived and targeted evaluations can
            provide solid evidence of what works and what doesn't
            work in the implementation of a program such as PNPM.
            Findings from such studies can provide policy
            recommendations to make improvements to project design and
            implementation, and also help to determine the future
            direction of the program.

16552592.majtheme: Public sector governance,Social protection and risk management,Rural development,Social dev/gender/inclusion

abstracts.cdata!:
The National Program for Community
            Empowerment or PNPM Mandiri is a nationwide program for
            community empowerment aimed at accelerating poverty
            reduction. The goal of this program is to empower rural and
            urban communities to proactively participate in development.
            PNPM will nurture the solidarity and spirit of cooperation
            within the community for self-help. The PNPM Support
            Facility (PSF) provides support to the Government of
            Indonesia's management and technical implementation of
            the overall PNPM Mandiri program, and harmonizes donor
            contributions. Through PSF, donors can provide high-quality,
            coordinated technical assistance, planning advice and
            dialogue, as well as targeted financial assistance to the
            Government of Indonesia (GOI) in support of PNPM Mandiri.
            The overall objective of PSF is to assist the GOI in
            providing the most effective leadership and management of
            the PNPM Mandiri. Its specific objectives are to: a) ensure
            better coordination across grants and amongst donors
            supporting PNPM Mandiri; b) develop capacity at all levels
            to plan, manage, and improve poverty reduction programs; c)
            reduce poverty through government and civil society
            partnerships; and d) support high quality monitoring and
            evaluation. The GOI is committed to maximizing management
            effectiveness during the PNPM Mandiri scale-up and
            developing capacity at the local government level. Toward
            this end, General Guidelines were issued to ensure that all
            involved parties, including all levels of government and
            PNPM Mandiri implementing staff, have the same understanding
            of PNPM Mandiri's principles and mechanisms.

repnme.cdata!:
Empowering Indonesian communities through
            developing infrastructure services

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            empowering Indonesian communities through developing
            infrastructure services. In 1998, Indonesia faced political
            upheaval and financial crisis. The country was marred by its
            graft-ridden political and administrative systems and
            poverty had increased tremendously. Non-income poverty was a
            serious problem in terms of high malnutrition and maternal
            mortality rates, inadequate access to safe water and
            sanitation, and education outcomes. Furthermore, inequality
            was increasing and disparities between regions remained
            high. Poverty alleviation had become a priority for
            Indonesia. To accelerate government efforts to reduce
            poverty and to ensure equity and inclusiveness, National
            Program for Community Empowerment Program named Nasional
            Pemberdayaan Masyarakat (PNPM), was announced by the
            government. With technical and financial assistance from the
            International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the
            PNPM became a national program covering all villages and
            cities in the country. PNPM Urban and PNPM Rural  Programs
            have built or rehabilitated over 62,000 kilometers of roads,
            11,000 clean water supply units, 11,000 irrigation schemes,
            6,500 kilometers of drainage, 17,500 village health posts
            and 10,000 new schools. Community participation in
            PNPM-Rural and PNPM-Urban is high. Also small
            poverty-reduction initiatives were be folded into the PNPM
            to make programming at the community level more streamlined,
            coordinated and responsive to beneficiaries’ needs.

repnme.cdata!:
Empowering Indonesian communities through
            developing infrastructure services

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            empowering Indonesian communities through developing
            infrastructure services. In 1998, Indonesia faced political
            upheaval and financial crisis. The country was marred by its
            graft-ridden political and administrative systems and
            poverty had increased tremendously. Non-income poverty was a
            serious problem in terms of high malnutrition and maternal
            mortality rates, inadequate access to safe water and
            sanitation, and education outcomes. Furthermore, inequality
            was increasing and disparities between regions remained
            high. Poverty alleviation had become a priority for
            Indonesia. To accelerate government efforts to reduce
            poverty and to ensure equity and inclusiveness, National
            Program for Community Empowerment Program named Nasional
            Pemberdayaan Masyarakat (PNPM), was announced by the
            government. With technical and financial assistance from the
            International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the
            PNPM became a national program covering all villages and
            cities in the country. PNPM Urban and PNPM Rural  Programs
            have built or rehabilitated over 62,000 kilometers of roads,
            11,000 clean water supply units, 11,000 irrigation schemes,
            6,500 kilometers of drainage, 17,500 village health posts
            and 10,000 new schools. Community participation in
            PNPM-Rural and PNPM-Urban is high. Also small
            poverty-reduction initiatives were be folded into the PNPM
            to make programming at the community level more streamlined,
            coordinated and responsive to beneficiaries’ needs.

            developing infrastructure services
